content.question:
This question is a long free-response question. Show your work for each part of the question.

(12 points, suggested time 25 minutes)

A block of mass <math alttext="m sub B" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>m</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>B</mi></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> can be attached to a parachute of negligible mass and radius <math alttext="r" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>r</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>, as shown in the two views above. When falling, the parachute experiences an upward force of air resistance. This force increases as the speed of the parachute increases. The falling block and parachute speed up at first but eventually reach a constant speed called terminal speed.

(a) The dot below represents the block-parachute system when it has reached its terminal speed and is falling at this constant speed. On the dot, draw and label the forces (not components) acting on the system. Represent each force by a distinct arrow starting on, and pointing away from, the dot.Note: Draw the relative lengths of all vectors to reflect the relative magnitudes of all the forces.

frqParts.text:
This question is a long free-response question. Show your work for each part of the question.

(12 points, suggested time 25 minutes)

A block of mass <math alttext="m sub B" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>m</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>B</mi></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> can be attached to a parachute of negligible mass and radius <math alttext="r" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>r</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>, as shown in the two views above. When falling, the parachute experiences an upward force of air resistance. This force increases as the speed of the parachute increases. The falling block and parachute speed up at first but eventually reach a constant speed called terminal speed.

(a) The dot below represents the block-parachute system when it has reached its terminal speed and is falling at this constant speed. On the dot, draw and label the forces (not components) acting on the system. Represent each force by a distinct arrow starting on, and pointing away from, the dot.Note: Draw the relative lengths of all vectors to reflect the relative magnitudes of all the forces.

A group of students has a collection of parachutes of different radii. They are curious about how the terminal speed depends on the radius of the parachute and find the following equation on the Internet.
                                                                                <math alttext="F sub air equals, C r v squared" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>F</mi></mrow><mrow><mtext>air</mtext></mrow></msub><mo>=</mo><mi>C</mi><mi>r</mi><msup><mrow><mi>v</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msup></mrow></mstyle></math>,
where <math alttext="F sub air" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>F</mi></mrow><mrow><mtext>air</mtext></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> is the force exerted by air, <math alttext="r" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>r</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> is the parachute’s radius, <math alttext="v" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>v</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> is the parachute’s speed, and <math alttext="C" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>C</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> is a constant that has appropriate units.
(b) Determine the units for <math alttext="C" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>C</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>.

The units for <math alttext="C" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>C</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> are ________ .

(c)

i. Based on the above equation for <math alttext="F sub air" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>F</mi></mrow><mrow><mtext>air</mtext></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>, derive an equation for the system’s constant terminal speed <math alttext="v sub t" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>v</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> in terms of <math alttext="r" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>r</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>, <math alttext="C" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>C</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>, physical constants, and other relevant quantities that can be measured with equipment usually found in a school physics laboratory, as appropriate. Assume the mass of the parachute is negligible and that the only nonnegligible forces acting on a block-parachute system are the block’s weight <math alttext="m sub B, end sub, times g" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>m</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>B</mi></mrow></msub><mi>g</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> and the force of air resistance <math alttext="F sub air" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>F</mi></mrow><mrow><mtext>air</mtext></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>.

ii. Indicate below what quantities could be measured and then graphed to determine whether the equation derived in part (c)(i) correctly relates the parachute’s radius and the terminal speed of the block-parachute system.
   Vertical axis: __________________          Horizontal axis: __________________
iii. On the axes below, sketch a graph showing the relationship between the two quantities indicated in part (c)(ii) and based on the equation derived in part (c)(i).

(d) Design an experimental procedure the students could use to collect the data needed to test whether or not the relationship between the parachute’s radius and the terminal speed is described by the graph drawn in part (c)(iii). Assume equipment usually found in a school physics laboratory is available.
In the table below, list the quantities that would be measured in your experiment. Define a symbol to represent each quantity, and also list the equipment that would be used to measure each quantity. You do not need to fill in every row. If you need additional rows, you may add them to the space just below the table.
Quantity to be MeasuredSymbol for QuantityEquipment for Measurement

Describe the overall procedure to be used, referring to the table. Provide enough detail so another student could replicate the experiment, including any steps necessary to reduce experimental uncertainty. As needed, use the symbols defined in the table. Include a simple diagram of the setup. As part of your description, be sure to explain how the students would know that they are measuring the constant terminal speed.
Diagram of Experimental SetupDescription of Experimental Procedure​​

(e) In another experiment, the students collect the following data showing the height of a block above the floor at different times, where the block is dropped from rest at time <math alttext="t equals 0" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> with the attached parachute fully open.

Time <math alttext="(in seconds)" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>(s)</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>
 Height of Block Above Floor <math alttext="(in meters)" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>(m)</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>

<math alttext="0.00" overflow="scroll"><mn>0.00</mn></math>
 <math alttext="1.35" overflow="scroll"><mn>1.35</mn></math>

<math alttext="0.10" overflow="scroll"><mn>0.10</mn></math>
 <math alttext="1.30" overflow="scroll"><mn>1.30</mn></math>

<math alttext="0.20" overflow="scroll"><mn>0.20</mn></math>
 <math alttext="1.18" overflow="scroll"><mn>1.18</mn></math>

<math alttext="0.30" overflow="scroll"><mn>0.30</mn></math>
 <math alttext="1.01" overflow="scroll"><mn>1.01</mn></math>

<math alttext="0.40" overflow="scroll"><mn>0.40</mn></math>
 <math alttext="0.82" overflow="scroll"><mn>0.82</mn></math>

<math alttext="0.50" overflow="scroll"><mn>0.50</mn></math>
 <math alttext="0.63" overflow="scroll"><mn>0.63</mn></math>

<math alttext="0.60" overflow="scroll"><mn>0.60</mn></math>
 <math alttext="0.43" overflow="scroll"><mn>0.43</mn></math>

<math alttext="0.70" overflow="scroll"><mn>0.70</mn></math>
 <math alttext="0.23" overflow="scroll"><mn>0.23</mn></math>

<math alttext="0.80" overflow="scroll"><mn>0.80</mn></math>
 <math alttext="0.03" overflow="scroll"><mn>0.03</mn></math>

Use the data shown above to determine the terminal speed of the block.

skill.text: 1.A: Create diagrams, tables, charts, or schematics to represent physical situations.
